overview_of_class: Plato admired Homer, but frequently finds himself criticizing him. In this course, we will read Homer alongside Plato in order to think about the value of literature and the substantive ethical ideals represented in these two authors. Is literature good for us? If so, how? Is it dangerous to read literature that puts forward a bad ethical model? What value, if any, do myths have in helping us to understand the world? What is it to be courageous? How do we understand courage within and outside of war? What role does knowledge or wisdom have in living a good life?

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The primarily goal is to learn how to think through philosophical issues, how to discuss what you understand and what puzzles you, and how to craft a paper that articulates a puzzle and presents a solution. In all of these activities, we will work on being exceptionally clear and careful. The secondary goal is to think through central questions about how to live and the value of literature that are raised by Homer and Plato.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Two short reaction papers (25%), a final paper (50%), presentations and class discussion (25%)

overview_of_class: In this course we will discuss the nature of work and money, and their roles in human life, as treated in classic philosophical texts.  The course is also therefore aimed to familiarize students with foundational texts in the philosophical tradition in social thought.  These texts concern - and we will discuss - not just the general nature of work or money, but also the characters of different sorts of work and the special moral or political problems they might pose, for example, "dirty" work, alienated work, traditionally unpaid women's work, etc.

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: In this course we will discuss the nature of work and money, and their roles in human life, as treated in classic philosophical texts. The course is also therefore aimed to familiarize students with foundational texts in the philosophical tradition in social thought. These texts concern - and we will discuss - not just the general nature of work or money, but also the characters of different sorts of work and the special moral or political problems they might pose, for example, "dirty" work, alienated work, traditionally unpaid women's work, etc.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
To introduce students to philosophical texts, and philosophical modes of interpreting and engaging with those texts

To encourage reflection about the meaning of work and the nature of money, and the appropriate place of each in human life

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Two meetings of 90 minutes each per week, comprising largely discussion.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be assigned based on class participation, writing assignments, and three papers (3-6 pp. each).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:

Coursepack including readings from Mencius; John Locke, Second Treatise of Government; Adam Smith, Wealth of Nations; Karl Marx, Economic and Political Manuscripts
